elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with diverse structures, adjustable pore sizes, and high surface areas have exhibited awesome potential in many fields. Here we report a simple carbonization strategy to obtain a series of core–shell structured Co/Co3O4 nanoparticles encapsulated into nitrogen-doped carbon shells from cobalt-based metal–organic framework precursors at different carbonization temperatures. When it is applied as an anodes for lithium ion batteries, the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode delivers a maximum initial discharge capacity of 1535 mAh g–1, the highest reversible capacity (903 mAh g–1 at a current density of 100 mA g–1 after 100 cycles), and the best rate performance (i.e., 774 mAh g–1 at a current density of 1.0 A g–1 after 100 cycles) in comparison with those of Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 electrodes. The excellent electrochemical performance could be mainly attributed to the unique core–shell structure, abundant graphited carbon, and the well-dispersed Co/Co3O4 nanoparticles which can promote the specific capacity through conversion reactions.

elements.content: A new layered cobalt-MOF (NUM-6) was designed, constructed, and used as a precursor for the preparation of core−shell Co/Co3O4@N-C nanocomposites. The electrochemical measurements indicate that the optimized sample, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700, shows a high reversible specific capacity, good cycling stability, and excellent rate performance, on evaluation as an anode for LIBs.

elements.content: Rechargeable lithium ion batteries (LIBs), as some of the most promising, highly efficient, and cost-effective energy storage techniques, have received sustained attention and have been applied in portable electronic devices and hybrid electrical vehicles because of their relatively high theoretical energy density, long cycling stability, low self-discharge, and no memory effect. Though LIBs have been commercialized since the 1990s, they still cannot meet the requirements of further markets. For this expectation, more and more efforts have been devoted to developing electrode materials, especially anode materials, to improve LIB performance. Presently, there have been mainly three kinds of widely studied anode materials, including commercial graphite, transition-metal oxides, and silicon, but all have various dissatisfactory aspects. For example, the commercial graphite anodes have a low theoretical capacity (LiC6, 372 mAh g–1) and low Li ion transport rate, while silicon anodes are limited by huge volume expansion (300–400%) during the lithium insertion/extraction process. In contrast, transition-metal oxides, with the advantages of low cost, high theoretical specific capacity (>600 mAh g–1), and high reversible capacity achieved by conversion reactions, have stood out from these common anode materials. Specifically, mixed-valence Co3O4 exhibits a high theoretical capacity of 890 mAh g–1 through an eight-electron conversion reaction, thus showing themselves to be promising anode materials for LIBs. However, its intrinsic poor electrical conductivity and huge volume expansion/extraction during the discharge and charge processes still hamper the widespread application of this material. To solve the aforementioned issues, many kinds of strategies have been proposed. One method is preparing the materials with controlled size and morphology, which can shorten the electronic and ionic diffusion distance and increase the contact area between electrode and electrolyte. Another strategy is assembling bicomponent-active Co3O4-based materials, such as Co3O4–Fe3O4, Co3O4–CoFe2O4, and Co3O4–ZnO. In addition, the design of electrode materials with hollow and polyhedral structures is also an effective approach. In addition to the methods mentioned above, coating carbon to form a core–shell structure has been proven to be a terrific strategy to solve the aforementioned issues because carbon can act as a layer to increase the conductivity and accommodate the volume changes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Rechargeable lithium ion batteries (LIBs), as some of the most promising, highly efficient, and cost-effective energy storage techniques, have received sustained attention and have been applied in portable electronic devices and hybrid electrical vehicles because of their relatively high theoretical energy density, long cycling stability, low self-discharge, and no memory effect. Though LIBs have been commercialized since the 1990s, they still cannot meet the requirements of further markets. For this expectation, more and more efforts have been devoted to developing electrode materials, especially anode materials, to improve LIB performance. Presently, there have been mainly three kinds of widely studied anode materials, including commercial graphite, transition-metal oxides, and silicon, but all have various dissatisfactory aspects. For example, the commercial graphite anodes have a low theoretical capacity (LiC6, 372 mAh g-1) and low Li ion transport rate, while silicon anodes are limited by huge volume expansion (300-400%) during the lithium insertion/extraction process. In contrast, transition-metal oxides, with the advantages of low cost, high theoretical specific capacity (>600 mAh g-1), and high reversible capacity achieved by conversion reactions, have stood out from these common anode materials. Specifically, mixed-valence Co3O4 exhibits a high theoretical capacity of 890 mAh g-1 through an eight-electron conversion reaction, thus showing themselves to be promising anode materials for LIBs. However, its intrinsic poor electrical conductivity and huge volume expansion/extraction during the discharge and charge processes still hamper the widespread application of this material. To solve the aforementioned issues, many kinds of strategies have been proposed. One method is preparing the materials with controlled size and morphology, which can shorten the electronic and ionic diffusion distance and increase the contact area between electrode and electrolyte. Another strategy is assembling bicomponent-active Co3O4-based materials, such as Co3O4-Fe3O4, Co3O4-CoFe2O4, and Co3O4-ZnO. In addition, the design of electrode materials with hollow and polyhedral structures is also an effective approach. In addition to the methods mentioned above, coating carbon to form a core-shell structure has been proven to be a terrific strategy to solve the aforementioned issues because carbon can act as a layer to increase the conductivity and accommodate the volume changes.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of inorganic–organic hybrid materials assembled by metal ions/clusters and organic linkers through coordination interactions to form an ordered structure. Recently, MOFs have been promising precursors or self-sacrificial templates to obtain various transition metal oxide based nanomaterials with special structures and morphologies, due to their advantages of diverse structure, adjustable pore size, and high surface area. In particular, MOF-derived Co3O4/carbon hybrids have shown high specific capacity and excellent cycling stability and rate performance when they are used as anode materials for LIBs. Han et al. reported the nitrogen-rich cobalt-based MOF [Co­(diimpym)­(npta)] n (diimpym = 4,6-bis­(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­pyrimidine, H2npta = 5-nitroisophthalic acid) and used it as precursor to obtain porous nitrogen-doped carbon-coated Co3O4 fish-scale composites. The results demonstrated that this kind of material delivered excellent electrochemical performance with a high capacity of 612 mAh g–1 at 1000 mA g–1 after 500 cycles. Sun and co-workers have also prepared porous hollow Co3O4 polyhedrons with nitrogen-doped carbon-coated composite (Co3O4/N-C) via pyrolysis of a cobalt-based MOF ([Co6O­(TATB)4]­(H3O+)2·Py), which exhibited high lithium storage capacity and outstanding cycling performance when they were applied as anode materials for LIBs. Therefore, using MOFs as precursors to prepare carbon-coated cobalt oxide nanocomposites has great potential. Despite the progress mentioned above, there is still room to design new MOF-derived core–shell Co-based electrode materials for superior performance.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of inorganic-organic hybrid materials assembled by metal ions/clusters and organic linkers through coordination interactions to form an ordered structure. Recently, MOFs have been promising precursors or self-sacrificial templates to obtain various transition metal oxide based nanomaterials with special structures and morphologies, due to their advantages of diverse structure, adjustable pore size, and high surface area. In particular, MOF-derived Co3O4/carbon hybrids have shown high specific capacity and excellent cycling stability and rate performance when they are used as anode materials for LIBs. Han et al. reported the nitrogen-rich cobalt-based MOF [Co(diimpym)(npta)] n  (diimpym = 4,6-bis(1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidine, H2npta = 5-nitroisophthalic acid) and used it as precursor to obtain porous nitrogen-doped carbon-coated Co3O4 fish-scale composites. The results demonstrated that this kind of material delivered excellent electrochemical performance with a high capacity of 612 mAh g-1 at 1000 mA g-1 after 500 cycles. Sun and co-workers have also prepared porous hollow Co3O4 polyhedrons with nitrogen-doped carbon-coated composite (Co3O4/N-C) via pyrolysis of a cobalt-based MOF ([Co6O(TATB)4](H3O+)2⋅Py), which exhibited high lithium storage capacity and outstanding cycling performance when they were applied as anode materials for LIBs. Therefore, using MOFs as precursors to prepare carbon-coated cobalt oxide nanocomposites has great potential. Despite the progress mentioned above, there is still room to design new MOF-derived core-shell Co-based electrode materials for superior performance.

elements.content: In this work, a new layered cobalt-MOF (NUM-6) based on mixed ligands of 4,4′,4″-((1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)­tris­(azanediyl))­tribenzoic acid (H3TATAB) and 2,4,6-tris­(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine (TPT) was designed, constructed, and used as a precursor for the preparation of core–shell Co/Co3O4@N-C nanocomposites. The carbonization temperature has a great influence on the electrochemical performance when these nanocomposites were evaluated as anodes for LIBs. In particular, the optimized sample Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 displays a higher reversible capacity and rate performance in comparison to those of Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 samples.

The carbonization temperature has a great influence on the electrochemical performance when these nanocomposites were evaluated as anodes for LIBs. In particular, the optimized sample Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 displays a higher reversible capacity and rate performance in comparison to those of Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 samples.

elements.content: All of the reagents and solvents, including cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co­(NO3)2·6H2O, AR, Aladdin), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, AR, Tianjin Concord), and ethanol (EtOH, 99.5%, Tianjin Concord), were commercially obtained and used without further purification. Distilled water was used in experiments. The organic ligands H3TATAB (C24H18N6O6, 4,4′,4″-((1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)­tris­(azanediyl))­tribenzoic acid) and TPT (C18H12N6, 2,4,6-tris­(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine) were synthesized according to the literature procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemicals

All of the reagents and solvents, including cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, AR, Aladdin), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, AR, Tianjin Concord), and ethanol (EtOH, 99.5%, Tianjin Concord), were commercially obtained and used without further purification. Distilled water was used in experiments. The organic ligands H3TATAB (C24H18N6O6, 4,4',4"-((1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)tris(azanediyl))tribenzoic acid) and TPT (C18H12N6, 2,4,6-tris(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine) were synthesized according to the literature procedures.

elements.content: Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (29 mg, 0.1 mmol), H3TATAB (24 mg, 0.05 mmol), and TPT (10 mg, 0.03 mmol) in 6 mL of a DMF/EtOH/H2O mixture (2/2/2, v/v/v) was sealed in a 10 mL vial and heated at 100 °C for 24 h. The orange crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield: about 80%.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Co3(TATAB)2(TPT)2(H2O)10]⋅DMF⋅4H2O (NUM-6)

Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29 mg, 0.1 mmol), H3TATAB (24 mg, 0.05 mmol), and TPT (10 mg, 0.03 mmol) in 6 mL of a DMF/EtOH/H2O mixture (2/2/2, v/v/v) was sealed in a 10 mL vial and heated at 100 °C for 24 h. The orange crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield: about 80%.

elements.content: Typically, the as-prepared Co-MOF (NUM-6) precursors were transferred into a tubular furnace and heated at different temperatures (T = 600, 700, 800 °C, respectively) with a heating rate of 5 °C min–1 under a nitrogen atmosphere for 4 h. After they were cooled to room temperature, the samples were then maintained in air at 250 °C for 30 min. Finally, the targeted materials were obtained and designated as Co/Co3O4@N-C-T (where T denotes the heating temperature, including 600, 700, and 800 °C: i.e., Co/Co3O4@N-C-700).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Co/Co3O4@N-C Nanocomposites

Typically, the as-prepared Co-MOF (NUM-6) precursors were transferred into a tubular furnace and heated at different temperatures (T = 600, 700, 800 °C, respectively) with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1 under a nitrogen atmosphere for 4 h. After they were cooled to room temperature, the samples were then maintained in air at 250 °C for 30 min. Finally, the targeted materials were obtained and designated as Co/Co3O4@N-C-T (where T denotes the heating temperature, including 600, 700, and 800 °C: i.e., Co/Co3O4@N-C-700).

elements.content: XRD patterns were tested by a Rigaku MiniFlex600 X-ray diffraction meter in a 2θ range of 3–80° at 40 kV and 15 mA with a Cu-target tube. The thermal stability of the NUM-6 precursor was conducted on a TGA instrument (Thermo plus EVO 2, TG8121). TEM (Tecnai G2F20S-TWIN) and energy dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDX) elemental mapping were used to identify the morphology of Co/Co3O4@N-C-T. A CHONS elemental analyzer (Vario EL cube) was used to confirm the contents of C and N elements. Raman spectra were collected on an Invia Reflex Raman spectrometer with a 632.8 nm laser. XPS was operated on a PHI5000 Versaprobe system. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements were performed on an ASAP 2020 instrument (Micromeritics) at 77 K, and the BET method was utilized to calculate the specific surface areas.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

XRD patterns were tested by a Rigaku MiniFlex600 X-ray diffraction meter in a 2θ range of 3-80° at 40 kV and 15 mA with a Cu-target tube. The thermal stability of the NUM-6 precursor was conducted on a TGA instrument (Thermo plus EVO 2, TG8121). TEM (Tecnai G2F20S-TWIN) and energy dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDX) elemental mapping were used to identify the morphology of Co/Co3O4@N-C-T. A CHONS elemental analyzer (Vario EL cube) was used to confirm the contents of C and N elements. Raman spectra were collected on an Invia Reflex Raman spectrometer with a 632.8 nm laser. XPS was operated on a PHI5000 Versaprobe system. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements were performed on an ASAP 2020 instrument (Micromeritics) at 77 K, and the BET method was utilized to calculate the specific surface areas.

elements.content: The diffraction data of NUM-6 were collected on a Rigaku 007HF XtaLAB P200 diffractometer at 293 K with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) by scan mode. The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELXTL program. Metal atoms in NUM-6 were located from the E maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were subsequently located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F 2. The H atoms of the coordinated water molecules in NUM-6 cannot be added in the calculated positions, and they were directly included in the final molecular formula. Part of the lattice solvent molecules were removed by the SQUEEZE program in PLATON and appended in the CIF file. Further details of crystal data and structure refinement for NUM-6 are summarized in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles of NUM-6 are given in Table S2. CCDC for NUM-6: 1817893.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The diffraction data of NUM-6 were collected on a Rigaku 007HF XtaLAB P200 diffractometer at 293 K with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) by scan mode. The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELXTL program. Metal atoms in NUM-6 were located from the E maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were subsequently located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F 2. The H atoms of the coordinated water molecules in NUM-6 cannot be added in the calculated positions, and they were directly included in the final molecular formula. Part of the lattice solvent molecules were removed by the SQUEEZE program in PLATON and appended in the CIF file. Further details of crystal data and structure refinement for NUM-6 are summarized in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles of NUM-6 are given in Table S2. CCDC for NUM-6: 1817893.

elements.content: The electrochemical performance was tested on CR2032-type coin cells which were assembled in an argon-filled glovebox (both O2 and H2O have a content <0.1 ppm). Lithium metal was used as the counter and reference electrodes. Taking Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 as an example, the working electrode was fabricated by continuously grinding a mixture of Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 nanocomposites, Ketjen black (KB), and poly­(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) at a mass ratio of 7:2:1 with N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) as the solvent to form a slurry. Then, the obtained slurry was uniformly coated on copper foil (∼0.9–1.1 mg per electrode) and dried overnight at 110 °C in a vacuum oven. The electrolyte was a solution of 1 mol L–1 LiPF6 dissolved in a mixture of dimethyl carbonate (DMC), ethylmethyl carbonate (EMC), and ethylene carbonate (EC) (1/1/1, v/v/v). Celgard 2400 membrane was used as a separator. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was tested on a VersaSTAT 4 electrochemical workstation (Princeton Applied Research) with a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s–1 between 0.01 and 3.00 V (vs Li/Li+). Discharge/charge tests were performed galvanostatically. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out on a VersaSTAT 4 electrochemical workstation (Princeton Applied Research) in a frequency range of 105–10–2 Hz at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Measurements

The electrochemical performance was tested on CR2032-type coin cells which were assembled in an argon-filled glovebox (both O2 and H2O have a content <0.1 ppm). Lithium metal was used as the counter and reference electrodes. Taking Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 as an example, the working electrode was fabricated by continuously grinding a mixture of Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 nanocomposites, Ketjen black (KB), and poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) at a mass ratio of 7:2:1 with N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) as the solvent to form a slurry. Then, the obtained slurry was uniformly coated on copper foil (~0.9-1.1 mg per electrode) and dried overnight at 110 °C in a vacuum oven. The electrolyte was a solution of 1 mol L-1 LiPF6 dissolved in a mixture of dimethyl carbonate (DMC), ethylmethyl carbonate (EMC), and ethylene carbonate (EC) (1/1/1, v/v/v). Celgard 2400 membrane was used as a separator. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was tested on a VersaSTAT 4 electrochemical workstation (Princeton Applied Research) with a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s-1 between 0.01 and 3.00 V (vs Li/Li+). Discharge/charge tests were performed galvanostatically. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out on a VersaSTAT 4 electrochemical workstation (Princeton Applied Research) in a frequency range of 105-10-2 Hz at room temperature.

elements.content: The formation diagram of core–shell Co/Co3O4@N-C nanocomposites is illustrated in a. First, the cobalt-based bulk MOF (NUM-6) was prepared under solvothermal conditions. NUM-6 crystallized in the triclinic P1̅ space group. Its asymmetric unit comprises three Co­(II) ions, two TATAB3–, two TPT, and ten water molecules. As shown in Figure S1 in the Supporting Information, Co1 and Co2 are six-coordinated by two O atoms from two TATAB3– ligands, one N atom from one TPT ligand, and three water molecules. Co3 is also six-coordinated by two N atoms from two TPT ligands and four water molecules. Each TATAB3– and TPT ligand is coordinated by two Co­(II) ions, and the adjacent TATAB3– and TPT ligands are bridged by the Co­(II) ions, resulting in a 2D layer. The powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD) pattern matches well with the simulated result, indicating the successful preparation of highly pure NUM-6 precursor (Figure S2a in the Supporting Information). Meanwhile, the thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) result indicates good thermal stability for NUM-6 (Figure S2b in the Supporting Information). More importantly, the unique 2D layered structure and high N amount make NUM-6 suitable to be used as a precursor for the preparation of Co-based electrode materials.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The formation diagram of core-shell Co/Co3O4@N-C nanocomposites is illustrated in a. First, the cobalt-based bulk MOF (NUM-6) was prepared under solvothermal conditions. NUM-6 crystallized in the triclinic P1̅ space group. Its asymmetric unit comprises three Co(II) ions, two TATAB3-, two TPT, and ten water molecules. As shown in Figure S1 in the Supporting Information, Co1 and Co2 are six-coordinated by two O atoms from two TATAB3- ligands, one N atom from one TPT ligand, and three water molecules. Co3 is also six-coordinated by two N atoms from two TPT ligands and four water molecules. Each TATAB3- and TPT ligand is coordinated by two Co(II) ions, and the adjacent TATAB3- and TPT ligands are bridged by the Co(II) ions, resulting in a 2D layer. The powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD) pattern matches well with the simulated result, indicating the successful preparation of highly pure NUM-6 precursor (Figure S2a in the Supporting Information). Meanwhile, the thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) result indicates good thermal stability for NUM-6 (Figure S2b in the Supporting Information). More importantly, the unique 2D layered structure and high N amount make NUM-6 suitable to be used as a precursor for the preparation of Co-based electrode materials.

elements.content: (a) Schematic illustration for the synthetic process of core–shell Co/Co3O4@N-C samples and (b) XRD patterns, (c) Raman spectra, and (d) nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of the as-synthesized Co/Co3O4@N-C at 600, 700, and 800 °C.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Schematic illustration for the synthetic process of core-shell Co/Co3O4@N-C samples and (b) XRD patterns, (c) Raman spectra, and (d) nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the as-synthesized Co/Co3O4@N-C at 600, 700, and 800 °C.

elements.content: Subsequently, the as-synthesized Co-MOF precursors were pyrolyzed in a tubular furnace at different targeted temperatures (T = 600, 700, 800 °C, respectively) followed by calcination in air at 250 °C to form Co/Co3O4@N-C-600, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700, and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 nanocomposites. The phase composition and crystallinity of all samples were first examined by XRD. As shown in b, the broad peaks at ca. 25.9° of three Co/Co3O4@N-C-T samples are ascribed to the typical carbon (002) peak, indicating the characteristic of graphite carbon material. With an increase in the pyrolysis temperature, the peak becomes narrower and the intensity of the peak becomes stronger, demonstrating that higher temperature is more favorable for the formation of carbon with better graphitization. In addition, the remaining peaks at 30.9, 36.7, 59.2, and 65.1° can be indexed to the (200), (311), (511), and (440) reflections of the cubic Co3O4 phase (JCPDS card No. 2-1079), respectively. Also, the peaks at 44.2, 51.5, and 75.9° are assigned to the (111), (200), and (211) planes of hexagonal-phase Co (JCPDS No. 1-1255), respectively. It should be noted that the Co3O4 phase of Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 shows the highest peak intensities while the Co phase presents relatively weak peak intensities in comparison with Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 nanocomposites, indicating that more Co phase is converted into the Co3O4 phase in Co/Co3O4@N-C-700. The carbon and cobalt compounds were calculated from TGA results, which can be seen in Figure S3 in the Supporting Information and are given in Table S3 in the Supporting Information. The Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 sample shows a relatively high content of cobalt compound in comparison with Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 samples, indicating that higher specific capacity could be obtained for the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 sample through a conversion reaction. No other impurities for the three samples are observed, confirming the successful preparation of Co/Co3O4@N-C nanocomposites. The existence of carbon and nitrogen doping was also characterized by Raman spectroscopy (c). The peaks at around 1355 and 1590 cm–1 correspond to the typical D and G bands, which represent characteristic features of disordered and graphitic carbon, respectively. The I D/I G ratios for Co/Co3O4@N-C-600, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700, and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 are 1.02, 1.01 and 1.03, respectively, indicating the existence of defects in obtained carbon compound, which is ascribed to the nitrogen doping derived from the organic linkers. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements were used to test the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of the as-prepared samples. As shown in d, all the samples exhibit typical type-IV curves and the BET surface areas of Co/Co3O4@N-C-600, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700, and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 are measured to be 186.4, 250.4, and 309.7 m2 g–1, respectively.

The peaks at around 1355 and 1590 cm-1 correspond to the typical D and G bands, which represent characteristic features of disordered and graphitic carbon, respectively. The I D/I G ratios for Co/Co3O4@N-C-600, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700, and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 are 1.02, 1.01 and 1.03, respectively, indicating the existence of defects in obtained carbon compound, which is ascribed to the nitrogen doping derived from the organic linkers. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements were used to test the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of the as-prepared samples. As shown in d, all the samples exhibit typical type-IV curves and the BET surface areas of Co/Co3O4@N-C-600, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700, and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 are measured to be 186.4, 250.4, and 309.7 m2 g-1, respectively.

elements.content: The morphologies of Co/Co3O4@N-C-600, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700, and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 samples were examined by transmission electron microscope (TEM) techniques. For Co/Co3O4@N-C-700, the low-resolution TEM images show that Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 exhibits a core–shell structure and is composed of small Co/Co3O4 nanoparticles with a main particle size of 14–53 nm, which are uniformly dispersed in the MOF-derived nitrogen-doped carbon framework, as seen in a,b. The core–shell structure was further evidenced by high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images. c shows that the particle was encapsulated by nitrogen-doped carbon layers. The carbon shell presents a typical graphene characteristic which is ascribed to the carbon being catalyzed by metallic Co during the carbonization process. The graphene layers are 7–10 layers thick. Meanwhile, d clearly reveals that the lattice fringe spaces of 0.156, 0.237, and 0.281 nm correspond to the (511), (311), and (220) crystal planes of the cubic Co3O4 phase, which is in good accordance with the XRD result. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) element mapping also unambiguously demonstrates that Co, O, C, and N elements are all uniformly distributed in the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 nanocomposite (e). For Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 samples, they show morphologies similar to that of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 sample, where the nanoparticles are dispersed in a MOF-derived carbon matrix, as seen in Figures S4 and S5 in the Supporting Information. However, in comparison with the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 sample, Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 displays a low graphitization degree and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 shows a relatively larger nanoparticle size of ca. 20–65 nm. This means that an increase in carbonization temperature can improve the graphitization degree of carbon materials, but it also accelerates the gradual aggregation of Co/Co3O4 nanoparticles. This phenomenon has also been proved by recently reported results. Elemental analysis was used to determine the content of C and N in three calcined samples, as seen in Table S4 in the Supporting Information. As the carbonization temperature is increased, the C content exhibits an increasing trend while the N content decreases, further indicating that elevating temperature could promote the graphitization degree of carbon and thus improve the electrical conductivity.

elements.content: To further identify the surface composition and chemical state of Co, C, and N in the three calcined samples, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were employed. Taking Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 as an example, the full spectrum first confirms the existence of Co, C, N, and O elements, which matches well the EDX elemental mapping result (a). In the high-resolution Co 2p spectrum (b), two major peaks appearing at 780.6 eV for Co 2p3/2 and 795.8 eV for Co 2p1/2 can be resolved into several peaks. The peak at around 779.9 eV is ascribed to Co0. The peaks at 781.0 and 795.2 eV are assigned to Co2+, which comes from the oxidation of the sample. The peaks with binding energies centered at 782.4 and 796.7 eV originate from Co3+ 2p3/2 and Co3+ 2p1/2, respectively. In addition, the shakeup satellite peaks located at 786.3, 789.7, and 804.7 eV are also observed in the Co 2p spectrum of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 nanocomposite, indicating the coexistence of Co2+ and Co3+ in the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 nanocomposite. This confirms that Co nanoparticles are partially transformed into the Co3O4 phase after calcination in air at 250 °C. For the C 1s spectrum, the peaks can be deconvoluted into four peaks at 284.8, 285.0, 286.2, and 288.9 eV, corresponding to C­(sp2)–C­(sp2), C–N, C–O, and OC–O bonds, respectively (c), demonstrating the high graphitic degree of the carbon. Meanwhile, the high-resolution N 1s XPS spectrum also contains three peaks located at 399.0, 400.4, and 401.3 eV which correspond to the pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N (d), respectively, demonstrating the successful doping of N in the carbon matrix of Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 nanocomposite. Similar results are also observed for Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 nanocomposites, as shown in Figures S6 and S7 in the Supporting Information. All the above analyses confirm the successful preparation of Co/Co3O4@N-C-T nanocomposites.

elements.content: The unique core–shell structure, high surface area, abundant graphited carbon, and well-dispersed Co/Co3O4 nanoparticles may endow the Co/Co3O4@N-C-T nanocomposites with excellent electrochemical performance when they are evaluated as anode candidate for LIBs. Due to the similar structure and composition among Co/Co3O4@N-C-600, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800, we just take Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 as an example to analyze the CV curve and the charge–discharge profile. a displays the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode for the first three cycles. The operating voltage range is between 0.01 and 3.00 V versus Li/Li+ at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1. In the first cycle, the cathodic peaks located at 0.64 and 0.85 V are assigned to the multistep electrochemical reduction of Co3O4 to metallic Co0, the generation of an irreversible solid–electrolyte–interphase (SEI) film on the electrode surface, and the formation of amorphous Li2O. Meanwhile, the appearance of another weak cathodic peak at 1.22 V also results from the formation of an SEI film and the decomposition of electrolyte, which is similar to the literature results. In the initial anodic scan, a broad peak appearing at 2.06 V corresponds to the oxidation of Co0 to Co2+ and Co3+. During the second and third cycles, the cathodic and anodic peaks shift positively to 1.03, 1.27, and 2.11 V, respectively, in comparison with the first cycle, indicating the polarization of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode. In addition, the decrease in peak intensities indicates that the specific capacity decays after the first cycle. The well-overlapped CV curves of the second and third cycles predict a good cycle stability of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 sample. The corresponding redox reactions are as follows: Co 3 O 4 + 8 Li + + 8 e − ⇌ 3 Co + 4 Li 2 O 8 Li ⇌ 8 Li + + 8 e − Co 3 O 4 + 8 Li ⇌ charge discharge 3 Co + 4 Li 2 O

elements.content: b displays the charge–discharge profiles of Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 at a current density of 100 mA g–1 during the 1st, 2nd, 10th, 50th, and 100th cycles. It is obviously that the open-circuit voltage for the first discharge process decreases quickly from 3.18 to 1.08 V, which is assigned to the insertion of lithium ion into Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 frameworks. Subsequently, a plateau at ca. 1 V followed by slow voltage attenuation to 0.01 V is ascribed to the reduction of Co3+ and Co2+ to metallic Co0 coupled with the formation of an SEI film and the decomposition of electrolytes. The initial discharge and charge specific capacities are 1535 and 830 mAh g–1, respectively, with an initial capacity retention ration of 54%. The irreversible capacity loss is mainly due to the inevitable formation of an SEI film, which results in an irreversible lithium consummation and the electrolyte decomposition. Then, the discharge specific capacities of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode in the 2nd, 10th, 50th, and 100th cycles basically are maintained at ca. 903 mAh g–1 and the Coulombic efficiencies of the 2nd, 10th, 50th, and 100th cycles can reach 91%, 97%, 99%, and 98%, respectively, indicating good cycle stability. The cycle performances of Co/Co3O4@N-C-T electrodes at a current density of 100 mA g–1 are shown in c. All Co/Co3O4@N-C-T electrodes display good cycling stability after 100 cycles with no apparent attenuation of specific capacity. Especially, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 exhibits the highest reversible capacity of 903 mAh g–1 in the 100th cycle, while Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 after 100 cycles show specific capacities of 509 and 460 mAh g–1, respectively. In addition, the Coulombic efficiencies of Co/Co3O4@N-C-600, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700, and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 samples can remain at nearly 98%, demonstrating the high reversibility of discharge and charge processes. In addition to the cycling stabilities, the rate performances of the as-synthesized Co/Co3O4@N-C-T samples have also been investigated. d displays the corresponding rate capabilities with an increase in the current densities per 10 cycles from 100 to 5000 mA g–1. For example, with current densities increasing from 100 to 200, 500, 1000, 2000, and 5000 mA g–1, the specific capacities of Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 sample decay from 852 to 791, 668, 571, 470, and 271 mAh g–1, respectively, indicating good rate performance. When the current density is recovered to 100 mA g–1, a specific capacity of 944 mAh g–1 is obtained, very close to the initial capacity. In comparison with the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 sample, both Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 samples exhibit poorer rate performance and lower reversible capacities.

elements.content: To further verify the good rate performance of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 nanocomposite, galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles were also tested at high current density. a shows the cycling stabilities of Co/Co3O4@N-C-600, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700, and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 samples at 1.0 A g–1 for 100 cycles. Similarly to the cycling performance at 0.1 A g–1, it can be seen that all Co/Co3O4@N-C-600, Co/Co3O4@N-C-700, and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 samples show good capacity retention and the corresponding specific capacities after 100 cycles are 569, 774, and 300 mAh g–1 with Coulombic efficiencies all being close to 99%, respectively, further indicating the good rate performance for the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 sample. Furthermore, in order to explain the electrochemical performance of these three electrodes, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was employed in the frequency range of 105–10–2 Hz. b displays the corresponding Nyquist plots. The semicircles in high- to medium-frequency regions are related to charge transfer resistances (R ct), and their diameters represent the R ct values, while the slope lines in the low-frequency region are associated with the Li+ ion diffusion resistances in the electrode. The smaller diameter of Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 in comparison with that of Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 or Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 indicates much better charge transfer ability and electrolyte permeation and thus induces the good electrochemical performance. It should be noted that the Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 sample with the poorest specific capacity and rate performance shows lower charge transfer resistance in comparison to that of Co/Co3O4@N-C-600. According to the literature result, a higher carbonization temperature is more beneficial for the formation of metallic cobalt species rather than Co3O4. In addition, the Co3O4 component with a theoretical capacity of 890 mAh g–1 mainly contributes to the specific capacity of the electrode material. On the basis of these two points, it is not difficult to understand why Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 exhibits higher specific capacity and rate performance in comparison to those of Co/Co3O4@N-C-800.

elements.content: In addition, to evaluate the effect of metallic Co on LIB performances, we also pyrolyzed NUM-6 precursors at 700 °C for 4 h under an N2 atmosphere and then calcined them in air for 8 h to entirely convert metallic Co to Co3O4. The obtained sample was denoted Co3O4@N-C-700. XRD was used to examine the phase composition of Co3O4@N-C-700 nanocomposite, and the result indicates that metallic Co was completely oxidized to Co3O4, as shown in Figure S8 in the Supporting Information. The cycling performance of Co3O4@N-C-700 was then tested at a current density of 1.0 A g–1, as shown in Figure S9 in the Supporting Information. It is seen that the specific capacity of the Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode is lower than that of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode, indicating that metallic Co can improve the electrochemical performance of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode. Many works have proved that metallic Co is inert and contributes little capacity to the electrode. Thus, we suppose that it may improve the electrical conductivity of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode. To verify this, EIS was employed (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information). In comparison with the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode, the Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode exhibits larger diameter in the high- to medium-frequency region. This result indicates that the introduction of metallic Co can indeed improve the electrical conductivity and promote the charge transfer of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode and thus increase the specific capacity. The morphology and phase composition of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode after 100 cycles at 100 mA g–1 were also examined by TEM and XRD. As shown in Figure S11a–c in the Supporting Information, the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 nanocomposite still maintains a well-dispersed and unique core–shell morphology after 100 cycles. Meanwhile, the XRD pattern (Figure S11d in the Supporting Information) shows that all peaks can be well assigned to the phases of carbon, Co3O4, and metallic Co. Both results indicate the good phase and structural stabilities of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode during repeated discharge/charge processes.

To verify this, EIS was employed (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information). In comparison with the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode, the Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode exhibits larger diameter in the high- to medium-frequency region. This result indicates that the introduction of metallic Co can indeed improve the electrical conductivity and promote the charge transfer of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode and thus increase the specific capacity. The morphology and phase composition of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode after 100 cycles at 100 mA g-1 were also examined by TEM and XRD. As shown in Figure S11a-c in the Supporting Information, the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 nanocomposite still maintains a well-dispersed and unique core-shell morphology after 100 cycles. Meanwhile, the XRD pattern (Figure S11d in the Supporting Information) shows that all peaks can be well assigned to the phases of carbon, Co3O4, and metallic Co. Both results indicate the good phase and structural stabilities of the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode during repeated discharge/charge processes.

elements.content: The reasons for the combination of high specific capacity and excellent rate performance can be ascribed to the synergistic effects among the unique core–shell architectures, highly graphitized carbon shell, and well-dispersed Co/Co3O4 nanoparticles of Co/Co3O4@N-C-T nanocomposites. First, the core–shell structure can well buffer the volume expansion/contraction during the discharge and charge processes, which can thus improve the cycling stabilities of the electrode materials. Second, the carbon shell with high graphitization can not only provide good electrical conductivity to promote the charge transformation and electrolyte infiltration but also contribute a certain specific capacity to the electrode. Third, the nanoscale and well-dispersed Co/Co3O4 particles could also promote the transformation of electrons and be used as active sites for the electrochemical reaction, which could achieve high capacity and weaken the lithiation-induced fracture of the electrode.

elements.content: In summary, a series of core–shell Co/Co3O4@N-C-T nanocomposites were prepared via a simple carbonization of Co-based MOF precursors and evaluated as anode materials for lithium ion batteries. The electrochemical measurements indicate that the optimized sample Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 shows a high reversible specific capacity, good cycling stability with nearly no fading of specific capacity after 100 cycles, and excellent rate performance. elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a series of core-shell Co/Co3O4@N-C-T nanocomposites were prepared via a simple carbonization of Co-based MOF precursors and evaluated as anode materials for lithium ion batteries. The electrochemical measurements indicate that the optimized sample Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 shows a high reversible specific capacity, good cycling stability with nearly no fading of specific capacity after 100 cycles, and excellent rate performance. The results exhibit that the core-shell structure, carbon coating, and well-dispersed Co/Co3O4 nanoparticles together play key roles in improving the electronic conductivity and electrochemical performance of the electrodes. This work suggests that designing and constructing N-rich Co-based layered MOF precursors are highly beneficial for the preparation of core-shell Co/Co3O4@N-C electrode materials with excellent electrochemical performance for lithium ion batteries.

cln_elements.content:
Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (29 mg, 0.1 mmol), H3TATAB (24 mg, 0.05 mmol), and TPT (10 mg, 0.03 mmol) in 6 mL of a DMF/EtOH/H2O mixture (2/2/2, v/v/v) was sealed in a 10 mL vial and heated at 100 °C for 24 h. The orange crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield: about 80%.

Preparation of Co/Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@N-C Nanocomposites

Typically, the as-prepared Co-MOF (NUM-6) precursors were transferred into a tubular furnace and heated at different temperatures (T = 600, 700, 800 °C, respectively) with a heating rate of 5 °C min–1 under a nitrogen atmosphere for 4 h. After they were cooled to room temperature, the samples were then maintained in air at 250 °C for 30 min. Finally, the targeted materials were obtained and designated as Co/Co3O4@N-C-T (where T denotes the heating temperature, including 600, 700, and 800 °C: i.e., Co/Co3O4@N-C-700).

Preparation of Co/Co3O4@N-C Nanocomposites

Typically, the as-prepared Co-MOF (NUM-6) precursors were transferred into a tubular furnace and heated at different temperatures (T = 600, 700, 800 °C, respectively) with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1 under a nitrogen atmosphere for 4 h. After they were cooled to room temperature, the samples were then maintained in air at 250 °C for 30 min. Finally, the targeted materials were obtained and designated as Co/Co3O4@N-C-T (where T denotes the heating temperature, including 600, 700, and 800 °C: i.e., Co/Co3O4@N-C-700).

cln_elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with diverse structures, adjustable pore sizes, and high surface areas have exhibited awesome potential in many fields. Here we report a simple carbonization strategy to obtain a series of core–shell structured Co/Co3O4 nanoparticles encapsulated into nitrogen-doped carbon shells from cobalt-based metal–organic framework precursors at different carbonization temperatures. When it is applied as an anodes for lithium ion batteries, the Co/Co3O4@N-C-700 electrode delivers a maximum initial discharge capacity of 1535 mAh g–1, the highest reversible capacity (903 mAh g–1 at a current density of 100 mA g–1 after 100 cycles), and the best rate performance (i.e., 774 mAh g–1 at a current density of 1.0 A g–1 after 100 cycles) in comparison with those of Co/Co3O4@N-C-600 and Co/Co3O4@N-C-800 electrodes. The excellent electrochemical performance could be mainly attributed to the unique core–shell structure, abundant graphited carbon, and the well-dispersed Co/Co3O4 nanoparticles which can promote the specific capacity through conversion reactions.
